poem:
Title: "Casualties in Normalcy"

In conflict's crude routine,
normalcy, draped over horror,
an Unrwa school in ruins—
33 lives lost,
each a universe quenched.

The West watches,
a wavering mirror reflecting 
fatalism's face.
Gaza is a lesson 
we can't unlearn,

the apple dropped 
on us, not Newton,
bloodying the Earth.
Not gravity, but grief pulls, 
unyielding in its truth.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘We have normalised horror’ says agency official, after Israeli strike on school Mass casualty incidents caused by the Israeli military offensive in southern Gaza are becoming normalised in the west and leading to a sense of fatalism inside Gaza itself, according to Sam Rose, the director of planning for the Palestinian relief agency Unrwa. He was speaking after an Unrwa school at Nuseirat was bombed by Israeli forces leaving at least 33 dead, including 12". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
